Slack Off gives it reliable recovery, which lets it effectively act as a defensive pivot or bulky sweeper without getting worn down. Scald is a STAB move that has a good chance to spread burns and further improves Mega Slowbro's bulk by burning physical attackers, making it very hard to break past. Psychic as Mega Slowbro's secondary STAB move allows it to hit Pokemon that resist Scald like Mega Venusaur and Toxapex. Psyshock may be used over Psychic to win Calm Mind wars and hit special walls, such as Chansey, significantly harder. However, Psyshock is less reliable against Toxapex, as most Toxapex are physically defensive.

Set Details

Maximum HP and Defense investment along with a Bold nature makes Mega Slowbro incredibly physical bulky, allowing Slowbro to switch in on Choice Band Diggersby to tank the hit and then Mega Evolve to tank the subsequent hit and prevent Diggersby from getting a clean KO. The spread also allows it to avoid a 2HKO from Tapu Bulu's Horn Leech. Slowbro has the ability Regenerator before Mega Evolving, letting it effectively act as a defensive pivot. Upon Mega Evolving, Mega Slowbro gains the ability Shell Armor, which allows it to safely use its setup moves.

Usage Tips

Avoid Mega Evolving Slowbro right away early-game, as it loses Regenerator upon Mega Evolving, which is incredibly useful for acting as a physical wall for Water teams. However, Slowbro should Mega Evolve as soon as possible against Normal teams to take on Choice Band Diggersby better. Early-game, Scald should be used often to spread burns and wear the opposing team down. Mega Slowbro has a mediocre Special Defense stat, so strong special wallbreakers like Mega Charizard Y, Tapu Koko, and Hydreigon need to be taken care of before it attempts to set up. Pokemon that carry Haze or phazing moves, such as Mantine, Swampert, and Empoleon, also need to be taken out before Mega Slowbro can attempt to set up. Status moves and entry hazards, such as Toxic and Toxic Spikes, should be avoided at all costs, as they make Mega Slowbro very easy to check by putting it on a timer. Against Water teams, Mega Slowbro should try to get burned by Scald, as this prevents the opposing team from using Toxic and crippling it, thus allowing it to set up effectively. Against Poison teams, Mega Slowbro should not switch into Toxic Spikes, as poison severely limits its ability to be a Calm Mind sweeper. Mega Slowbro can set up on passive Pokemon such as Toxapex, but one must scout for Toxic first to ensure safe setup.

Team Options

Toxapex has very good synergy with Mega Slowbro, as it provides a neutrality to Grass and forms a Regenerator core with Slowbro, which can be very hard for opposing teams to break. Toxapex can even check threats such as Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona, provide Toxic Spikes support for Mega Slowbro, and absorb Toxic Spikes. Swampert, Gastrodon, and Lanturn provide Mega Slowbro with a crucial Electric immunity, checking threats like Tapu Koko and Magnezone. Swampert also provides Stealth Rock support, which is useful for wearing down opposing teams and making types like Bug and Flying easier to deal with; Gastrodon has reliable recovery and good mixed bulk that allows it to better check Electric-type Pokemon for Mega Slowbro; and Lanturn can provide Heal Bell support, making it hard for opposing teams to wear down Mega Slowbro through Toxic. Mantine helps Mega Slowbro by checking special attackers such as Hydreigon and Volcarona. Additionally, it provides Defog support so that Mega Slowbro is not plagued by entry hazards like Toxic Spikes. Choice Scarf Greninja is a good teammate, as it can check fast threats such as Tapu Bulu and Tapu Koko as well as Dragon-types like Hydreigon and Latios. Keldeo breaks down walls such as Chansey, which are obstacles for Mega Slowbro if they carry Toxic. Keldeo also checks Dark-types like Hydreigon, while Mega Slowbro provides a defensive backbone for Keldeo by coming in on strong physical moves. Gyarados helps to check Grass-types such as Breloom and Tapu Bulu by utilizing its Flyinium Z set. Gyarados also acts as a secondary sweeper for Water teams and makes certain matchups, such as against Bug, a little easier. Sap Sipper Azumarill is a great teammate, as it not only provides a valuable Grass immunity to the team for checking threats such as Tapu Bulu and Breloom, but also acts as a check to Dragon-types like Hydreigon for Mega Slowbro. Azumarill can also take out walls such as Celesteela and Ferrothorn, with its Perish Song trapping set, which makes it easier for Mega Slowbro to set up. Suicune is a good teammate for Mega Slowbro, as it helps pressure Mega Slowbro's checks, making it difficult for a team to beat both.

Iron Defense (Water).description:
Moves

Calm Mind allows Mega Slowbro to patch up its lackluster Special Defense stat and tank special hits from threats like Latios and Greninja after a few Calm Mind boosts. Iron Defense allows Mega Slowbro to boost its gigantic Defense even further and shrug off strong setup sweepers such as Garchomp and Mega Pinsir, turning Mega Slowbro into an impenetrable force. Scald is the only STAB move on the set, as it offers good utility by having a very good chance to burn physical threats such as Tapu Bulu and Belly Drum Azumarill. Rest not only allows Mega Slowbro to fully regain its health but also makes Mega Slowbro unafraid of status-inducing moves such as Toxic.

Set Details

Maximum HP and Defense investment along with a Bold nature allows Mega Slowbro to be as physically bulky as possible and reliably check most physical attackers, including Diggersby. Regenerator as a pre-Mega ability allows Slowbro to be an effective defensive pivot for Water teams that is hard to wear down. Once it has Mega Evolved, it gains the ability Shell Armor, which gives it an easier time setting up.

Usage Tips

It is important to not Mega Evolve early-game, as this causes Mega Slowbro to lose out on Regenerator, which is very important for it to stay healthy during the match and act as a reliable wall for Water teams. Since Mega Slowbro has pretty lackluster Special Defense, it should not be switched in against strong special attackers such as Landorus, as it risks getting severely weakened. Mega Slowbro should attempt to use Calm Mind against physical attackers like Mega Lopunny and Mega Gallade as well as walls, as such Pokemon cannot do much damage to it in return and it can boost its Special Defense to endure special attackers on the opposing team. As Mega Slowbro relies on setup moves to pose a defensive threat, Taunt users such as stallbreaker Mew and Jellicent need to be removed before it can attempt to set up. Haze users such as Mantine and Toxapex also need to be removed, as these Pokemon can easily nullify all of Mega Slowbro's boosts and waste its PP. Additionally, Poison-types like Mega Venusaur and Toxapex need to be taken care of, as Mega Slowbro's only attacking move is Scald and both of these Pokemon resist the move. Mega Slowbro should use Rest to get rid of status conditions such as poison and set up on status inducers like Celesteela. Rest should also be used to keep Mega Slowbro healthy to allow it to better tank hits from special attackers once it starts setting up Calm Mind, while Iron Defense should be used to check physical setup sweepers and Z-Move users such as Gyarados, Bisharp, and Belly Drum Azumarill.

Team Options

Teammates that can cover Mega Slowbro's weakness to Electric such as Swampert and Gastrodon are appreciated. Both of these Pokemon can provide additional support for it, with Swampert using Stealth Rock to wear down Mega Slowbro's checks and counters and Gastrodon having reliable recovery and good mixed bulk to fare better against Electric teams. Toxapex provides a neutrality to Grass, which is important for checking threats such as Mega Venusaur. Additionally, Toxapex can provide Toxic Spikes support to wear down teams for Mega Slowbro and can also stop special set up sweepers such as Volcarona with Haze. Mantine can check strong special attackers such as Mega Charizard Y and Hydreigon as well as provide Defog support so that Mega Slowbro is not worn down by entry hazards such as Toxic Spikes, which may force it to use Rest. For stall teams, Alomomola is another good teammate that acts as a good mixed wall and can relieve pressure on Mega Slowbro to check physical attackers. It also forms a Regenerator core with Slowbro that is very hard to break past, provides Wish support to help with recovery, and checks threats such as Mega Venusaur by utilizing Mirror Coat. Sap Sipper Azumarill covers Water's weakness to Grass-type moves and checks Pokemon such as Breloom and Tapu Bulu, which can cripple or break past Mega Slowbro. It has an additional immunity to Dragon, allowing it to check Pokemon like Hydreigon. Teammates that can break the Mega Venusaur + Toxapex core such as Flyinium Z Gyarados and Groundium Z Greninja are also good teammates for Mega Slowbro. Keldeo is a good partner for Mega Slowbro, as it can take care of Water-immune Pokemon such as Mantine and Seismitoad with Hidden Power Electric and Secret Sword.

Muk-Alola.overview:
Poison

Alolan Muk is the premier specially defensive Pokemon for Poison teams by virtue of its above-average bulk and decent offensive presence. Additionally, its secondary Dark typing gives it a very important immunity to Psychic while leaving it with a single weakness in Ground. Alolan Muk's great bulk is only enhanced by its ability to efficiently run an Assault Vest, allowing it to serve as a great switch-in to strong special attackers such as Mega Charizard Y. Alternatively, Curse allows Alolan Muk to act as a bulky setup sweeper. The combination of Iapapa Berry and Gluttony grants Alolan Muk a reliable form of recovery, allowing it to set up Curse with ease. Access to Pursuit allows Alolan Muk to trap and eliminate otherwise dangerous Psychic-types such as Latios as well as Ghost-types like Blacephalon with certainty. Alolan Muk also has access to a strong STAB Knock Off, allowing it to remove the foe's item. This allows it to be very useful against Pokemon that rely on their items such as Eviolite Chansey and Choice-locked Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Greninja. Alolan Muk's ability Poison Touch allows it to potentially wear down switch-ins such as Mantine by granting its contact moves a 30% chance to poison and stacks with Poison Jab for an overall 51% chance to poison. Despite its above-average special bulk, however, Alolan Muk has no way to recover its HP if it uses Assault Vest, so it can often be quickly worn down. On top of this, Alolan Muk's physical bulk leaves a lot to be desired and can be exploited by strong physical attackers such as Mega Gallade. Alolan Muk's Speed is also very lackluster, leading to it failing to outspeed just about any offensive Pokemon and certain problematic walls such as Celesteela.

Dark

Alolan Muk is the best Dark-type defensive check to Fairy-types with its Poison / Dark typing giving it a neutrality to Fairy. To supplement that already good defensive typing, it also has great special bulk and can serve as one of Dark's more reliable special walls. In addition to switching into Fairy-types, Alolan Muk's can take out Fairy-types such as Tapu Koko that are often difficult to KO for Dark teams thanks to its STAB Poison Jab. Poison Jab combines especially well with Poison Touch and makes Alolan Muk capable of spreading poison around very easily and risky to switch into. Its use of Knock Off and Pursuit makes it even harder to switch into or switch out of, as Alolan Muk can remove items like Porygon2's Eviolite and trap Pokemon such as Alolan Raichu. Outside of STAB attacks, it has good coverage moves in Rock Slide to hit Volcarona and Fire Punch to hit Klefki and Ferrothorn, all of which are threats to Dark teams. However, when its attacks aren't super effective, Alolan Muk's underwhelming offensive stats means that it can barely even damage walls and rarely threatens even attackers outside of poison. Even though Assault Vest Alolan Muk can take big special hits, its physical bulk is average, meaning physical attackers can take it on easily, and it has no way to heal at all, making it easy to slowly take down over time. Curse gives Alolan Muk use against types that Dark typically struggles against, such as Electric and Fairy. Curse synergizes extremely well with Alolan Muk's fantastic defensive typing and special bulk, letting it act as a massive threat after a boost or two. It also has reliable recovery by means of Gluttony, Iapapa Berry, and Recycle.
Muk-Alola.comments:
Other Options

Poison

Rock Slide is an option that allows Alolan Muk to check Pokemon such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y much more efficiently, exploiting their massive Rock weakness.

Dark

There are no other viable options for Alolan Muk.

Checks and Counters

Poison

Ground-types: Many Ground-types such as Excadrill, Landorus, and Garchomp can take advantage of Alolan Muk's sole weakness in Ground and KO it with their STAB moves.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Although Alolan Muk is still able to remove their items, Pokemon such as Mega Steelix, Skarmory, and Toxapex can threaten Alolan Muk due to their good physical bulk.

Physical Attackers: Alolan Muk's average Defense stat means it struggles to switch into most strong physical attacks, such as Terrakion and Mega Gallade's Close Combat and Mega Diancie's Diamond Storm.

Burns: Burns from the likes of Mega Sableye's Will-O-Wisp and Toxapex's Scald will cripple Alolan Muk and prevent it from having an offensive presence.

Dark

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Garchomp and Hippowdon are typically unafraid of Alolan Muk's attacks and can either OHKO or cripple it with their super effective STAB attacks.

Physical Wallbreakers: Alolan Muk's below average Defense makes it quite vulnerable to being OHKOed by physical attackers such as Choice Band Terrakion and Choice Band Victini.

Walls: While walls tend to hate taking Knock Off or getting poisoned, Alolan Muk ultimately can't really touch most walls such as Slowbro and Mantine, as they'll typically have recovery to outlast it.

Steel-types: Although a few don't enjoy taking Fire-type attacks, most Steel-types such as Skarmory and Celesteela are relatively unafraid of Alolan Muk, as they cannot be poisoned.

Residual Damage: Because Alolan Muk lacks recovery, residual damage from burns and entry hazards is permanent on Alolan Muk and can prevent it from properly checking threats for the team.

Knock Off: Knock Off from Pokemon like Mega Sableye and Clefable permanently cripples Curse Alolan Muk for the remainder of the game, as it can't heal with Iapapa Berry after it has been removed.

Taunt: Taunt prevents Curse Alolan Muk from boosting and healing, effectively beating it.

Curse (Poison).description:
Moves

Curse allows Alolan Muk to act as a bulky setup sweeper. Knock Off is Alolan Muk's main attack and grants it the ability to remove a foe's item such as Kyurem-B's Life Orb. Pursuit allows Alolan Muk to trap Pokemon that are looking to switch out, namely Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon such as Blacephalon and Latios, which can threaten the team otherwise. Poison Jab is an option over Pursuit that allows Alolan Muk to hit Fairy- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Tapu Bulu and Mandibuzz. Recycle allows Alolan Muk to reuse its Iapapa Berry after it has been eaten.

Set Details

248 HP and 12 Defense EVs allow Alolan Muk to tank Choice Scarf Victini's V-create after Stealth Rock damage. The remaining EVs go into Special Defense to maximize Alolan Muk's special bulk, allowing it to tank hits such as Latios's Draco Meteor. Gluttony allows it to consume Iapapa Berry earlier, giving Alolan Muk access to a reliable form of recovery.

Usage Tips

Since Alolan Muk depends on its Iapapa Berry and Recycle to keep its HP high, it should avoid getting its Iapapa Berry removed by moves such as Trick and Knock Off. Additionally, Alolan Muk should Recycle its Iapapa Berry as often as it can to keep its health as high as possible for later in the game. Alolan Muk should also avoid burns, as it depends on its Attack stat to successfully do damage. Use Knock Off to remove foes' items such as Chansey's Eviolite and Victini's Choice Scarf. Also, switch Alolan Muk into predicted Psychic-type attacks such as Latios's Psychic and proceed to trap the foe with Pursuit; do the same to take on Ghost-types such as Gengar and Blacephalon and weakened threats such as Protean Greninja after it has changed types.

Team Options

Alolan Muk benefits the whole team by providing a key immunity to Psychic-type attacks and the ability to Pursuit trap Psychic-type threats. Crobat is immune to Ground and creates a solid defensive core with Alolan Muk. Additionally, Crobat can act as the team's Defogger, prevent walls from recovering damage with Taunt, and take on threats such as Mega Gallade and Kommo-o with Brave Bird. Mega Venusaur provides a neutrality to Ground-type attacks for Alolan Muk. Additionally, it can take on Water- and Ground-type Pokemon with Giga Drain and provide Alolan Muk with Leech Seed recovery. Toxapex provides the team with Toxic Spikes, which wears down the opposing team and allows Alolan Muk to muscle past its checks with more ease. Additionally, it can fish for burns with Scald, allowing Alolan Muk to set up more easily against physical attackers. Toxapex can also switch into weak attacks and easily brush them off thanks to Recover and Regenerator. Nidoking provides the team with an Electric immunity and has amazing coverage moves such as Flamethrower, allowing it to hit Pokemon such as Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn, and Thunderbolt and Ice Beam, which allow it to hit all Pokemon for neutral damage. Choice Scarf Nihilego is a faster Stealth Rock setter that can act as the team's revenge killer, since it can outspeed threats such as +1 Mega Charizard X and Garchomp. Salazzle has the unique ability of being able to poison Poison- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Toxapex and Heatran. Additionally, it can also take on Steel- and Grass-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn with Flamethrower. Scolipede and Gengar are less viable options on Poison teams, but they do match up well against Psychic-type teams, which Poison otherwise struggles with, freeing up Alolan Muk to use Poison Jab over Pursuit.

Assault Vest (Poison).description:
Moves

Pursuit enables Alolan Muk to trap and pressure Psychic-types such as Alolan Raichu as well as general special attackers that it forces out such as Magnezone. Knock Off is usually Alolan Muk's strongest STAB move and can be useful for removing items such as Eviolite and Leftovers from the foe. Poison Jab's considerably high chance to poison the foe allows it to be a good secondary STAB move that can wear down many of Alolan Muk's switch-ins, such as Mega Sableye. Fire Blast offers useful coverage to hit Pokemon such as Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn. Its main purpose, however, is to avoid Alakazam's Counter, allowing Alolan Muk to safely break its Focus Sash and proceed to trap it. Although weak, Shadow Sneak is a decent option that allows Alolan Muk to fire off a move before going down, since it's very slow, and pick off weakened Psychic-types such as Victini.

Set Details

The given EV spread maximizes Alolan Muk's special bulk and allows it to always survive Choice Scarf Victini's V-create after a round of Stealth Rock. Poison Touch gives Alolan Muk's contact moves a respectable chance to poison defensive switch-ins such as Landorus-T. Assault Vest enhances Alolan Muk's special bulk to incredible levels, allowing it to fully serve as an amazing check to many of the metagame's special attackers such as Tapu Koko. A Sassy nature is used in order to increase Alolan Muk's Special Defense while not sacrificing Fire Blast's power. However, if a physical move is run over it, then a Careful nature is preferred.

Usage Tips

Alolan Muk's main role is that of a special pivot, so it is safe to bring it in on special attackers such as Tapu Koko and Porygon-Z while it's healthy. However, since it has no way of recovering HP, Alolan Muk should not be worn down unnecessarily throughout the match. Avoid switching into entry hazards unless necessary in order to preserve HP. It is especially important to preserve Alolan Muk in matchups where it is needed to trap dangerous Pokemon such as Blacephalon and Latios, as these Pokemon have a much easier time against the rest of the team. Because of this, Alolan Muk is absolutely crucial in the Psychic matchup, as its stops Pokemon like Mew from simply using their super effective STAB moves and it puts consistent pressure in the matchup thanks to Knock Off and Pursuit. When trapping frailer Psychic-types such as Latios, it is always better to use Pursuit right away, as it will heavily damage them even if they choose to stay in. Alakazam should never be Pursuit trapped while at full HP, however, as it will always survive a hit thanks to its Focus Sash and KO Alolan Muk back with its Counter. Lastly, Alolan Muk should avoid burns from Will-O-Wisp and Scald, as this will cripple its otherwise respectable Attack stat and allow it to become setup bait for certain Pokemon such as Mega Charizard X.

Team Options

Mega Venusaur is a physically defensive tank that synergizes very well with Alolan Muk, as it can stomach physical attacks with its bulk as well as take on Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Swampert. Alolan Muk, on the other hand, can take on Psychic-types as well as most special attackers that can break past Mega Venusaur such as Volcarona. Toxapex completes an amazing defensive core between the two of them, as Regenerator in tandem with its ability to set Toxic Spikes goes hand in hand with Alolan Muk's ability to force switches and take on Pokemon such as Porygon-Z for it. Additionally, Toxapex can serve as a good physical switch-in and even burn physical attackers with Scald. Crobat is a good teammate, sporting a notable immunity to Ground, utility in the form of Taunt and Defog, and access to Flying-type STAB moves, allowing it to deal with stops to Alolan Muk such as Keldeo. Nidoking is a great special wallbreaker that can specifically eliminate Steel-types that trouble Alolan Muk, such as Skarmory, Ferrothorn, and Celesteela, as well as provide Stealth Rock support for the team. Thanks to the presence of Pokemon such as Skarmory and Landorus-T, Alolan Muk often struggles in the Flying matchup. Nihilego is a great teammate that can cover this, as its coverage is almost impossible to wall in this matchup, and it can also set up its own Stealth Rock. Lastly, Gengar can free Alolan Muk's load in the Psychic and Ghost matchups thanks to its great offensive typing and can take on more offensive Pokemon such as Mega Gallade after minimal chip damage.

Curse (Dark).description:
Moves

Knock Off is Alolan Muk's strongest STAB attack, providing secondary utility by removing items such as Klefki's Light Clay and Porygon2's Eviolite. Poison Jab gives Alolan Muk coverage for Dark-resistant Pokemon such as Mega Diancie, Mandibuzz, and Keldeo, has a chance to poison, and lets it act as a sweeper against Fairy teams. Curse lets Alolan Muk set up on a plethora of attackers and sweep teams. It also gives it Alolan Muk potential to take on opposing physical attackers such as Mega Sharpedo and Mega Aerodactyl. Recycle combined with Iapapa Berry gives Alolan Muk a form of reliable recovery.

Set Details

Gluttony lets Alolan Muk use a Berry after it drops to half its health or below. This, in conjunction with Iapapa Berry and Recycle, gives it reliable recovery. 248 HP and 12 Defense EVs let Alolan Muk survive Victini's V-create and KO it. The Special Defense EVs and a Careful nature maximize Alolan Muk's special bulk, which works well with Curse mitigating its weakness to any physical attackers.

Usage Tips

Keep Alolan Muk as healthy as possible throughout a game by using Recycle frequently, especially against types such as Water where it's more useful as a check to special attackers than as a setup sweeper. Similarly, if Alolan Muk can provide more utility through Knock Off, bide your time and don't try to force yourself into setting up until late-game when checks such as Choice Band Victini are weakened or KOed. Curse Alolan Muk's claim to fame is founded in the Fairy matchup, so set up against weaker Pokemon, notably Klefki and Choice-locked Tapu Bulu, and look out for Knock Off users like Azumarill and Clefable. Also, it will rarely be capable of outright sweeping from the get-go, so weaken some of its checks and go for setup late-game. Checks like Choice Band Diggersby are capable of switching in on Curse and forcing Alolan Muk out, so attacking them on the switch, especially early-game, could leave them crippled and potentially prevent them from checking Alolan Muk later on. Similarly, try to spread poison via Poison Jab to wear down checks. Knock Off does significantly less damage once the foe's item has been removed, so use Poison Jab in these cases for higher damage output. Avoid status, specifically burn and paralysis, and at all costs avoid Knock Off, as Alolan Muk losing its Iapapa Berry will cripple it for the entire game.

Team Options

Hydreigon has Taunt to beat checks to Alolan Muk such as Taunt Gliscor and Haze Toxapex. It also provides a Ground immunity, forcing some prediction with opposing Ground-types like Nidoking. Knock Off from Alolan Muk helps Hydreigon break down walls like Porygon2 as well. Mega Sableye is able to bounce back status-inducing moves like Will-O-Wisp and entry hazards like Stealth Rock that quickly wear down Alolan Muk. It also weakens physical attackers, giving Alolan Muk more freedom to set up. Alolan Muk can be supported by means of Pursuit from Krookodile or Weavile to take care of some of its more common checks, notably Choice Band Victini and Diggersby. Tyranitar is able to spread status, set Stealth Rock to wear down foes for Alolan Muk, and take care of special threats, giving Alolan Muk more room to set up and relieving some of the pressure that special attackers force on it. Mandibuzz is able to clear hazards and check physical attackers like Mega Lopunny and Azumarill that Alolan Muk would otherwise struggle with. Greninja can force out wallbreakers like Diggersby that beat Alolan Muk as well as set up Spikes to soften offensive checks lacking recovery.

Assault Vest (Dark).description:
Moves

Knock Off is a decent STAB attack that removes items, helping to take on Eviolite users such as Chansey and allowing Alolan Muk to more easily beat some Choice item users like Diggersby. Poison Jab is the preferred Poison-type STAB move because it has a 51% chance of poisoning targets thanks to Poison Touch and is reliable for beating Fairy-types. Rock Slide is a great coverage option that OHKOes huge threats to Dark teams such as Volcarona. It also almost always OHKOes Mega Charizard Y and deals significant damage to Mega Pinsir to prevent it from setting up safely. Fire Punch hits Steel-types such as Klefki and Mega Scizor better than any of Alolan Muk's other moves do, preventing them from setting up on Alolan Muk. Fire Blast does have a few advantages over Fire Punch, though, in being able to avoid contact with Ferrothorn, 2HKO Bisharp, and prevent Alakazam from using Counter, but Fire Blast does suffer from worse accuracy. Pursuit is also an option over a coverage move to hit Pokemon as they switch out, which can be helpful for taking out or at least chipping away at Pokemon such as Alolan Raichu and Mantine that Alolan Muk forces out.

Set Details

248 HP and 12 Defense EVs means that even after Stealth Rock, Alolan Muk will never be OHKOed by V-create from Choice Scarf Victini. The rest of the EVs are put into Special Defense to maximize Alolan Muk's special bulk. A Careful nature is used with an Assault Vest to improve Alolan Muk's Special Defense even more. If Fire Blast is used, a Sassy nature should be used to avoid lowering its damage output. Poison Touch gives Alolan Muk an additional 30% chance to poison its targets and is especially effective with Poison Jab.

Usage Tips

Alolan Muk can easily switch into most special attackers with its great bulk, and passive walls such as Chansey typically can't threaten it thanks to its Poison typing, so take advantage of these foes early-game to bring Alolan Muk into play often. If Alolan Muk is carrying Pursuit, you can play more riskily and switch it directly in against Pokemon it wants to trap, such as Latios, in order to secure the KO. Try to keep entry hazards such as Stealth Rock away to avoid making Alolan Muk take unnecessary damage, as the lack of recovery means that damage will add up fairly quickly. Early-game, use Knock Off liberally to remove as many of the opposing team's items as possible. For example, against Fairy teams, removing the enemy Klefki's Light Clay is a top priority early on to limit the number of turns that Reflect and Light Screen will halve the damage you deal. While using Knock Off, Alolan Muk should also use Poison Jab frequently to spread poison. In this way, Alolan Muk can cripple walls like Porygon2 in two ways, both by removing a crucial item such as Eviolite and by poisoning them. Be careful when trying to poison walls that can burn Alolan Muk, such as Mega Sableye and Mantine, though, as it hates being burned. In addition to halving Alolan Muk's Attack, burns start the timer on how long Alolan Muk can act as a wall. Make sure to preserve Alolan Muk's health in matchups where it is needed to check a high priority threat. For example, against Bug teams, Rock Slide Alolan Muk is the most reliable check to Volcarona, as even a +2 Inferno Overdrive with Stealth Rock support can't OHKO Alolan Muk, so it is important to not let Alolan Muk take too much damage early on.

Team Options

Alolan Muk is a great teammate for almost all Dark teams, as it serves as a Fairy check for offensive teams and a very bulky special wall for more balanced teams. Entry hazard control is important for preserving Alolan Muk's HP, so Mega Sableye and physically defensive Mandibuzz are frequent partners for Alolan Muk, as Magic Bounce can prevent Stealth Rock from coming up and Mandibuzz can Defog hazards if they get past Mega Sableye. Together, the trio form a great defensive core as well, covering all weaknesses effectively. While Sand Stream will chip away at Alolan Muk, Tyranitar is still a good option for supporting Alolan Muk. Tyranitar can use Pursuit, letting Alolan Muk bring coverage moves instead, and it also has Stealth Rock to help punish the switches that Alolan Muk can easily force. With Levitate, Hydreigon makes for a more offensive teammate that can help beat Ground-types for Alolan Muk. Hydreigon also takes on physical walls and particularly Steel-types very effectively, so Alolan Muk may find it easier to drop Fire-type coverage for other options. Greninja is another strong offensive Ground check, as its Ice Beam threatens almost every Ground-type. Greninja also uses U-turn for pivoting into Alolan Muk easily and Gunk Shot to relieve some of the pressure on Alolan Muk to check Fairy-types. Weavile can be helpful for relieving pressure on Alolan Muk, as it sometimes runs Pursuit to enable Alolan Muk to choose other coverage moves and can offensively check most Ground-types such as Garchomp.

Cloyster.overview:
Water

Cloyster is an amazing setup sweeper and late-game cleaner due to its access to Shell Smash, one of the best setup moves in the game. Cloyster's Skill Link ability in conjunction with moves like Icicle Spear and Rock Blast allows it to have very high-Base Power moves while also breaking potential Focus Sashes on Pokemon such as Breloom. A sky-high Defense stat allows Cloyster to set up Shell Smash against most physical attackers with ease, and a good offensive Water / Ice typing gives Cloyster opportunities to sweep many types, including Grass, Ground, Dragon, and Flying, once its checks have been taken care of. However, a lack of coverage moves forces Cloyster to rely on the less powerful Hydro Pump to hit Steel-types. Cloyster also has relatively low offensive stats, which means it needs to set up to be an offensive threat, and its very low special bulk makes it take lots of damage from even weak special attacks. This, combined with a poor defensive typing with only two resistances, means Cloyster can have a hard time finding appropriate setup opportunities. This causes it to be extremely reliant on a Focus Sash to help it set up, and this reliance on Focus Sash also causes Cloyster to be very vulnerable to priority, which can revenge kill it easily. A mediocre Speed stat causes Cloyster to be outsped by most offensive threats, some such as Choice Scarf Latios and Swift Swim Kingdra even after a Shell Smash. Finally, it can be hard to justify Cloyster a teamslot when it is outclassed in most situations by other late-game cleaners and setup sweepers such as Mega Sharpedo, Gyarados, and Azumarill.

Ice

Cloyster is one of the most threatening Ice-type sweepers due to its Water typing and access to Shell Smash, which allows it to sweep types such as Fire and Rock if given the chance to set up. A neutrality to both Fire- and Steel-type moves allows Cloyster to heavily influence these matchups with Rock Blast and Hydro Vortex, being able to set up on Pokemon such as Infernape locked into Flare Blitz and Excadrill with ease. Furthermore, Cloyster's good offensive ability in Skill Link allows it to make good use of moves like Icicle Spear and Rock Blast, enabling it to break through Focus Sash from Pokemon such as Breloom, Alakazam, and Araquanid. A gargantuan Defense stat means it can set up in front of many physical attackers such as Excadrill and Mega Swampert easily. However, an abysmal Special Defense leaves Cloyster vulnerable to any decently strong special hit and diminishes its ability to set up as easily. Even resisted special hits, such as Scald from Keldeo, will dent Cloyster. Low offensive stats mean it is further dependent on a Shell Smash boost to pose as an offensive threat, since it doesn't hit very hard unboosted. Cloyster's mediocre Speed stat makes it somewhat easy to revenge kill, since it cannot outspeed key threats such as Choice Scarf Latios, and due to its vulnerability to entry hazards and Shell Smash's defense-lowering effect, it's easy to chip it down, possibly leaving it vulnerable to opposing priority moves such as Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Breloom's Mach Punch.
Cloyster.comments:
Other Options

Water

White Herb mitigates the defense drops from Shell Smash, but the safety offered by Focus Sash is more helpful.

Ice

A Naughty nature can be used, but the loss in Speed isn't worth it, as Cloyster would be outsped by several Choice Scarf users such as Infernape, Blacephalon, and Terrakion. However, it does let Cloyster secure a 2HKO on Mega Swampert after very slight chip damage, as well as giving it more power before setting up Shell Smash, which it slightly lacks with a Naive nature. White Herb can be used to make Cloyster less vulnerable to priority and revenge killing; however, it sorely misses the one time nuke Waterium Z provides.

Checks and Counters

Water

Bulky Water-types: Pokemon such as Mega Slowbro, Tapu Fini, and Toxapex resist both of Cloyster's STAB moves, allowing them to easily take any hit. They are then able to status it, hit it hard, or remove its boosts, depending on the Pokemon.

Special Attackers: Due to Cloyster's pitiful Special Defense stat, fast special attackers like Alakazam and Porygon-Z are able to easily OHKO it if it has not yet set up. Cloyster cannot even switch into resisted special attacks, as they will still do large damage to it.

Priority: Cloyster's reliance on Focus Sash to set up means that it will usually be at 1 HP while sweeping, so fast priority such as from Weavile and Dragonite can easily revenge kill it. However, if Cloyster is using Ice Shard, it may be able to get one hit off against slower priority users before getting KOed.

Electric-types: Most Electric-types are very fast and have high offensive stats, allowing them to OHKO Cloyster before it has set up or even outspeeding it after it has set up. In particular, Alolan Raichu can outspeed Cloyster in Electric Terrain even after a Shell Smash and OHKO it with Thunderbolt. Magnezone can survive any hit from Cloyster and OHKO it in return, and Rotom-W can take any of Cloyster's attacks before pivoting out with Volt Switch.

Steel-types: Steel-types resist all of Cloyster's physical attacks, forcing it to rely on the weaker Hydro Pump to hit them. Bulky Steel-types such as Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn are able to easily take any of Cloyster's attacks even at +2 and can KO or outlast it.

Fighting-types: Even though most Fighting-types are physical, they are still able to deal massive damage to Cloyster, especially after a Shell Smash. While most of them are unable to tank hits from +2 Cloyster, Keldeo fears nothing from Cloyster and priority from Infernape or Breloom can pick Cloyster off.

Ice

Water-types: Water-types resist both of Cloyster's STAB moves and are mostly unaffected by Rock Blast, which can give free turns to several key threats to Ice teams such as Keldeo, which can launch a powerful attack, and Toxapex, which can freely set up Toxic Spikes.

Special Attackers: Due to its pathetic Special Defense stat, Cloyster will easily crumble to even relatively weak or resisted special attacks. While this is mitigated if Aurora Veil has been set up beforehand, it is still quite disappointing—for example, it won't even be able to take any attack from Choice Scarf Latios if it has taken Stealth Rock damage.

Faster Choice Scarf users: Any Choice Scarf user with base 110 Speed or higher will be able to outspeed Cloyster even after it has set up a Shell Smash, meaning Pokemon like Gengar, Greninja, and Latios can easily revenge kill it, especially after prior chip damage.

Entry Hazards: Cloyster absolutely hates having to take unnecessary damage, since it heavily relies on its natural bulk, further supported by Aurora Veil, to set up and endure priority attacks. This means the extra damage taken from entry hazards, Stealth Rock in particular, can mean the difference between sweeping a team and being taken out either while setting up or versus a faster foe.

Phazers and Haze Users: Pokemon such as Avalugg, Swampert, and Toxapex can stop a Cloyster sweep cold due to their ability to erase its stat boosts through Roar or Haze.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Very physically bulky Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Porygon2, and Quagsire are able to take Cloyster's attacks and retaliate, beating it one-on-one.

Status: Status moves are heavily detrimental to Cloyster, since it relies on all of its speed, power, and longevity, which paralysis, burns, and bad poison severely reduce.

Shell Smash Sweeper (Water).description:
Moves

Shell Smash is what allows Cloyster to sweep, raising all of its offensive stats by two stages while lowering its defensive stats. Icicle Spear is Cloyster's main STAB move, which has an effective 125 Base Power thanks to Skill Link. It can also break Focus Sashes on Pokemon that could stop Cloyster's sweep. Rock Blast is a good coverage move that is affected by Skill Link and helps against Bug, Ice, and Fire teams. Ice Shard is a priority move that can be used to revenge kill threats before setting up and also hits Choice Scarf Latios, which would otherwise outspeed and KO Cloyster even after a Shell Smash. It can also be used to outprioritize threats such as Diggersby that attempt to revenge kill Cloyster with their own priority attacks. Hydro Pump is a secondary STAB move that hits physically defensive Pokemon such as Forretress and Skarmory, especially those that resist Icicle Spear.

Set Details

Maximum Attack and Speed investment makes the most of Cloyster's sweeping potential, allowing it to outspeed most threats after a Shell Smash and making Icicle Spear and Rock Blast hit as hard as possible. A Jolly nature gives Cloyster even more Speed and should be used with Ice Shard; on the other hand, a Naive nature boosts Cloyster's Speed without decreasing the power of Hydro Pump. Skill Link makes Icicle Spear and Rock Blast always hit five times and gives them an effective 125 Base Power, allowing Cloyster to break through many threats. Focus Sash almost guarantees a safe setup opportunity for Cloyster by allowing it to survive at least one attack.

Usage Tips

Preserve Cloyster until near the end of the match, as it can be a great late-game cleaner once its checks have been weakened or removed. Since it is best to keep Cloyster at full HP to let it effectively set up Shell Smash, it is helpful to bring Cloyster in freely on a slow U-turn or Volt Switch from the likes of Pelipper or Lanturn or after an ally has been KOed. Similarly, entry hazards must be off the field before sending Cloyster in, especially as it is weak to Stealth Rock and the entry hazards will break its Focus Sash; it is very difficult to set up with Cloyster if its Focus Sash does not work. On the other hand, Cloyster can also sometimes utilize its massive Defense stat to switch into some physical attackers like Gyarados and Mimikyu and set up against them. Since Cloyster generally only has one chance to sweep, attempt to get rid of its checks and counters—in particular, bulky Water-types—before setting up. Similarly, priority users such as Dragonite and Weavile should also be removed before setting up, as they can revenge kill Cloyster when it's down to 1 HP. If Cloyster is running Ice Shard, it can also come in against weakened threats and revenge kill them.

Team Options

Tapu Fini and Mantine can use Defog to clear the entry hazards that can wear down Cloyster while also offering defensive utility; Mantine's Grass neutrality and amazing special bulk allow it to switch into many attacks that threaten Cloyster, while Tapu Fini's Misty Surge ability allows it to easily absorb status. Pelipper can set rain, which makes Hydro Pump hit much harder, while also sporting a Grass neutrality along with access to U-turn, which allows Cloyster to be brought in easily. In a similar vein, Rotom-W offers a slow Volt Switch that gives Cloyster free opportunities to switch in. It also has an Electric neutrality and can burn foes with Will-O-Wisp, slowly chipping at them. Lanturn also sports an Electric immunity thanks to Volt Absorb, can heal Cloyster of any status ailments with Heal Bell, and has access to Volt Switch to allow it to pivot into Cloyster easily. Entry hazard setters such as Swampert and Empoleon can set up Stealth Rock, which aids Cloyster's sweeping potential. Strong wallbreakers such as Greninja and Keldeo are able to weaken many foes and physical walls, allowing Cloyster to clean late-game. Z-Move users such as Azumarill, Manaphy, and Gyarados are great sweepers that can wear down shared checks with Cloyster.

Shell Smash Sweeper (Ice).description:
Moves

Shell Smash is an amazing setup move that enables Cloyster to sweep unprepared teams. Icicle Spear is Cloyster's main STAB attack, and coupled with Skill Link, it essentially reaches 125 Base Power. Hydro Pump, coupled with Waterium Z, enables Cloyster to bypass many of its would-be checks and counters such as Skarmory and Mega Scizor once it has set up. Regular Hydro Pump hits Steel-types for neutral damage, which otherwise would be able to wall Cloyster completely. Rock Blast is extremely useful to hit Fire-types that Hydro Pump can't hit super effectively such as Mega Charizard X and Torkoal, and it also comes in handy in the Bug and mirror Ice matchup, all of which are much harder without Cloyster. It can also hit Water-types that resist its STAB moves, but it doesn't hit particularly hard because of a lack of type advantage.

Set Details

Waterium Z enables Cloyster to use Hydro Vortex, which, with 144 Special Attack EVs, secures an OHKO on Mega Scizor at +2 after Stealth Rock. These EVs also ensure Cloyster OHKOes Skarmory with Hydro Pump when at +2. 252 Speed EVs and a Naive nature are necessary to avoid being outsped by common Choice Scarf users such as Terrakion and Infernape. The remaining EVs are poured into Attack to power up Icicle Spear and Rock Blast. Skill Link is the ability of choice due to it allowing Icicle Spear and Rock Blast to always hit five times, making them very reliable attacks.

Usage Tips

Due to its monstrous physical defense, Cloyster is able to easily set up on most non-super effective physical hits such as Infernape locked into Flare Blitz. Setting Aurora Veil with Alolan Ninetales helps Cloyster tremendously while setting up, allowing it to set up on even strong super effective moves like Horn Leech from Choice Scarf Tapu Bulu and on some weak special attackers it otherwise wouldn't be able to, such as Clefable. Make sure to clear Stealth Rock and other entry hazards when attempting a sweep with Cloyster; the chip damage taken from them can be extremely detrimental when trying to set up. This is especially important versus Pokemon that can hit Cloyster super effectively such as offensive Scizor and versus specially offensive Pokemon like Choice Scarf Keldeo, which OHKO it if any hazard is up. Weakening Water-types with Pokemon like Kyurem-B and Alolan Ninetales is necessary due to them resisting both of Cloyster's STAB attacks and taking little damage from Rock Blast, which allows Pokemon such as Slowbro and Toxapex to completely wall it. Ideally, you should save Cloyster for late-game once its checks and counters have been removed from the game, though it could be used to occasionally switch into a physical attack for its teammates, especially versus types like Flying, which don't tend to carry priority or fast Choice Scarf users. However, be extremely careful of switching Cloyster into attacks, since it may compromise its ability to set up later. Cloyster should not attempt to set up on Pokemon that can status it with moves like Scald, Will-O-Wisp, and Thunder Wave, such as Toxapex, Mega Sableye, and Klefki.

Team Options

Alolan Ninetales is an excellent partner for Cloyster, since it can set up Aurora Veil for it, which can help immensely while setting up, and check Fighting-type Pokemon, which can check Cloyster themselves. It can also use Encore on passive foes such as Celesteela to create setup opportunities and deal with bulky Water-types for Cloyster with Freeze-Dry. Kyurem-B is a terrifying wallbreaker for Ice teams that can pave the way for a Cloyster sweep due to its ability to heavily damage Pokemon like Toxapex and Mega Venusaur for it. Mamoswine and Piloswine can both set up Stealth Rock for Cloyster and its other teammates, which is a consistent way of dealing chip damage to Pokemon like Mega Venusaur. In addition, running Piloswine means Mamoswine is free to run a wallbreaking set, which can help break down Pokemon such as Porygon2 for Cloyster. Its access to Ice Shard can heavily damage Latios, which is a Choice Scarf user that can outpace Cloyster even at +2. Avalugg can use Rapid Spin to further support Cloyster when setting up, allowing it to stay at full health and helping it take decently strong super effective hits from the likes of Armaldo. Alolan Sandslash can run utility options; either Rapid Spin or Swords Dance are useful for Cloyster, since the former allows it to provide hazard removal support to its teammates and the latter lets it break through troublesome walls such as Toxapex with a boosted Earthquake. Rotom-F can provide useful Defog support and beat several Water- and Steel-types such as Toxapex and Scizor with its STAB Thunderbolt and Hidden Power Fire. Weavile is able to Pursuit trap troublesome Pokemon for Ice teams such as Victini and Latios with ease. Its access to priority in Ice Shard also allows it to pick off weakened foes such as Gengar, which Cloyster appreciates.

Gengar.overview:
Ghost

With high Speed and Special Attack, Gengar serves as an effective revenge killer, wallbreaker, and cleaner for Ghost. Choice Scarf Gengar's excellent Speed tier allows to outrun most of the unboosted metagame as well as most other Choice Scarf users. Gengar's Poison typing also comes in handy for absorbing Toxic Spikes against Poison and Water teams as well as putting heavy pressure on types such as Fairy. Gengar has a colorful movepool with coverage options such as Thunderbolt for Mantine, Trick for disabling walls such as Chansey and Zapdos, and Destiny Bond to lure and remove certain targets that threaten Ghost, such as Alolan Muk and Bisharp. Gengar is very, very frail, however, and is easily taken out by Pokemon that it cannot KO first. Its low defenses also leave it checked by strong priority users such as Scizor and Azumarill. Gengar is very vulnerable to Pursuit trappers such as Alolan Muk and Mega Aerodactyl, the former of which can switch in on any of Gengar's attacks and take it out consistently. Despite high Special Attack, the relatively low power of Shadow Ball and poor coverage of Sludge Wave as STAB attacks limit what Gengar can check effectively.

Poison

Gengar's high Speed and Special Attack make it an effective revenge killer and late-game cleaner, especially for Poison teams seeking an edge in the Psychic matchup. Its varied movepool gives it good offensive coverage and options to hit most switch-ins for significant damage, such as Focus Blast to hit Heatran. It can also cripple checks such as Chansey and Zapdos with Trick. However, Gengar's moves are individually easy to check, so locking it into one with Choice Scarf can give opponents undue momentum, and Gengar's frailty means it has few opportunities to switch in and leaves it vulnerable to any attacker that it cannot KO first, although a Normal immunity can be useful to force Diggersby into mind games. In addition, Gengar faces competition as a revenge killer from Nihilego, which offers useful defensive utility with a unique Flying resistance as well as handy STAB coverage for pressuring Flying teams.
Gengar.comments:
Other Options

Ghost

Destiny Bond can be used over Trick on Choice Scarf Gengar as an emergency button against offensive threats that it cannot KO reliably such as Mega Gyarados and Volcarona. It can also be used over Focus Blast alongside Trick to form a lure set for Alolan Muk. However, outside of this niche and the added utility of Choice Scarf Destiny Bond, there isn't much reason to use it over Focus Blast. Ghostium Z or Electrium Z offers Gengar a one-time nuke to remove certain defensive threats such as Toxapex and Celesteela. However, the Z-Move is generally preferable on other team members.

Poison

Thunderbolt is a useful coverage option that can be run over Trick to threaten switch-ins such as Mantine and Toxapex. However, Thunderbolt's utility is generally limited compared to Trick, and Poison has other means of addressing these threats. A Life Orb all-out attacker set can be used should Choice Scarf Nihilego be run, but this set is a generally worse wallbreaker than Nidoking and is more easily checked. Destiny Bond is an option over Trick so that Gengar can act as an emergency check to setup sweepers such as Suicune and Z-Move Calm Mind Keldeo that can't be checked otherwise.

Checks and Counters

Ghost

Alolan Muk: Alolan Muk can easily switch into any of Gengar's attacks with its excellent typing and bulk and remove it from the battle using Pursuit.

Pursuit: Pursuit trappers such as Tyranitar and Mega Aerodactyl have an easy time trapping Gengar by taking advantage of it locking itself into Shadow Ball or Sludge Wave, preventing it from confidently checking offensive threats.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Mega Sableye and Mandibuzz can easily shrug off Choice Scarf Gengar's attacks and KO it in return with Dark-type attacks.

Ground-types: Ground-types resist Sludge Wave and usually are bulky enough to take Shadow Ball easily, making it easy for threats such as Hippowdon, Landorus, and Garchomp to KO it in return with super effective STAB moves.

Specially Defensive Walls: Gengar's mediocre damage output leaves it comfortably walled by common special walls such as Zapdos and Chansey, although Gengar can cripple these Pokemon using Trick.

Priority: Due to Gengar's frailty, powerful priority attackers such as Azumarill, Scizor, and Bisharp can easily KO it and force Gengar's team on the defensive.

Faster Revenge Killers: Non-Choice Scarf Gengar can easily be KOed by opposing revenge killers that outspeed it such as Mega Lopunny, Tapu Koko, and Greninja.

Poison

Alolan Muk: Alolan Muk hard counters Gengar and can easily switch into any of its attacks and remove it from the battle using Pursuit.

Pursuit Trappers: Other Pursuit trappers such as Tyranitar and Mega Aerodactyl have an easy time trapping Gengar by taking advantage of it locking itself into Shadow Ball or Sludge Wave, and they can prevent it from confidently checking offensive threats.

Immunities: All of Gengar's attacks have Pokemon immune to them: Steel-types are immune to Sludge Wave, Normal-types are immune to Shadow Ball, and Ghost-types are immune to Focus Blast. Thus, the presence of any of these immunities on a team can make Gengar very prediction heavy and easy to take advantage of.

Ground-types: Ground-types resist Sludge Wave and are generally bulky enough to survive Shadow Ball easily, making it easy for threats such as Hippowdon, Landorus, and Garchomp to KO Gengar in return with super effective STAB moves.

Specially Defensive Walls: Gengar's mediocre damage output leaves it easily walled by common special walls such as Zapdos and Chansey, although Gengar can cripple these threats with Trick.

Priority: Due to Gengar's frailty, powerful priority attackers such as Azumarill, Scizor, and Bisharp can easily KO it and force Poison on the defensive.

Choice Scarf (Ghost).description:
Moves

Shadow Ball is Gengar's most spammable STAB move with excellent coverage for checking offensive threats. Sludge Wave is Gengar's most powerful STAB attack and is useful for hitting key threats such as Tapu Koko, but it comes with the downside of having more resistant targets than Shadow Ball. Focus Blast is useful Fighting-type coverage for hitting important Steel-, Normal-, and Dark-types such as Tyranitar, Mega Lopunny, and Heatran. Trick is handy utility for disabling specially defensive walls that Gengar cannot break such as Zapdos and Chansey.

Set Details

Maximum Special Attack investment is used so that Gengar hits as hard as possible, while maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature and a Choice Scarf allow Gengar to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame as well as the majority of opposing Choice Scarf users. Cursed Body is Gengar's only ability and gives contact moves used against Gengar a 30% chance of being disabled.

Usage Tips

Gengar should be used to revenge kill offensive threats that Ghost's defensive core cannot manage, such as Life Orb Greninja and Mega Diancie, or to clean late-game. Be careful to preserve Gengar in matchups where it is necessary to check threats to the team such as Mega Lopunny or where its STAB moves are particularly useful, such as against Fairy. Use Trick to disable threatening walls to the team such as Gliscor and Chansey. However, take care not to use Trick until threats like Tapu Koko, which Gengar needs Choice Scarf to check, have been removed. Be careful leaving Gengar in while Pursuit trappers such as Alolan Muk and Mega Aerodactyl are in play. Likewise, be careful when picking a move to lock into, as all of Gengar's attacks have types immune to them. Avoid Thunder Wave because the Speed reduction severely diminishes Gengar's capacity to check offensive threats.

Team Options

Mega Sableye is a defensive staple of Ghost and part of the defensive backbone that supports Gengar, removing opposing Pokemon's items and spreading burns. In return, Gengar manages threats that beat Mega Sableye such as Tapu Koko and Clefable. Jellicent is a specially defensive wall that helps the defensive backbone Ghost falls back on for threats Gengar cannot manage. Decidueye and Gourgeist can also support the defensive backbone as a switch-in for powerful Ground-types such as Excadrill and Landorus. Mimikyu is an excellent blanket check for offensive threats that threaten Gengar and Ghost in general, such as Bisharp, Mega Sharpedo, and Mega Lopunny. Choice Specs Blacephalon is a complementary special attacker that supports Gengar by breaking through special walls such as Zapdos and Toxapex. Alolan Marowak and Golurk serve as powerful physical attackers that can also set Stealth Rock to chip Gengar's checks as they switch in. In return, Gengar does an excellent job taking on faster foes for these slow attackers.

All-out Attacker (Ghost).description:
Moves

Shadow Ball is Gengar's most spammable STAB move, having excellent offensive coverage for wallbreaking. Sludge Wave is Gengar's most powerful STAB attack, hitting useful targets such as Zapdos and Volcarona, but it comes with the downside of having more resistant targets. Focus Blast is excellent coverage that hits important threats such as Tyranitar and Heatran. Taunt is handy utility for disabling specially defensive walls such as Zapdos and Mantine, which might otherwise stall Gengar out with Life Orb recoil. Thunderbolt is an option over Taunt for hitting Water- and Flying-types such as Toxapex, Mantine, and Celesteela harder as well as OHKOing threats such as Mega Charizard Y after some chip damage. However, it comes with the cost of not being able to wear down threats such as Zapdos and Chansey. Destiny Bond is an option over Taunt for luring and removing certain threats to Ghost such as Alolan Muk and Bisharp.

Set Details

Maximum Special Attack investment with a Life Orb is used so that Gengar hits as hard as possible. Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature allows Gengar to tie with the crowded base 110 Speed tier and outrun most of the unboosted metagame, including key threats such as Keldeo and Volcarona. Cursed Body is Gengar's only ability, giving contact moves used against Gengar a 30% chance of being disabled.

Usage Tips

Gengar should be used as a speedy wallbreaker, checking slower offensive Pokemon such as Keldeo and Diggersby and punishing switch-ins. However, be careful about leaving Gengar in if there are Pursuit trappers such as Alolan Muk on the field. Taunt should be utilized to keep walls such as Zapdos and Chansey from recovering health and stalling out Gengar with recoil damage. However, make sure that such walls don't use the opportunity to launch an attack, as Gengar cannot take much punishment from even weak attackers. Preserve Gengar in matchups where it is necessary to check threats to the team such as Toxapex and Celesteela. When using Destiny Bond, take care not to reveal the move until the opportunity presents itself to lure a key threat such as Alolan Muk. Destiny Bond can also be used against Sucker Punch users such as Bisharp to keep them from using Sucker Punch on the subsequent turn at the risk of being KOed.

Team Options

Mega Sableye is the lifeblood of Ghost teams and part of the defensive backbone that Gengar falls back on against opposing offense. In return, Gengar can check Pokemon that threaten Mega Sableye such as Toxapex and Clefable. Jellicent is a specially defensive wall that takes on for threats Gengar cannot manage, such as bulky Water-types like Gastrodon and Seismitoad, and can spread status with Toxic and Scald. Grass-types such as Decidueye and Gourgeist can also support this defensive backbone by managing dangerous Ground-types such as Excadrill. Mimikyu is an excellent blanket check for attackers such as Bisharp, Mega Sharpedo, and Mega Lopunny. Mimikyu appreciates Gengar taking out defensive walls that check it such as Toxapex and Mega Venusaur so it can clean late-game. Blacephalon is a complementary special attacker that can serve as a Choice Scarf revenge killer and cleaner for Ghost, taking advantage of the holes left by Gengar in opposing teams' defensive cores. Alolan Marowak and Golurk serve as physical attackers and Stealth Rock setters that can chip some of Gengar's checks, such as Celesteela and Mantine, on their switch in.

Choice Scarf Attacker (Poison).description:
Moves

Shadow Ball is Gengar's most spammable STAB move and allows it to apply enormous pressure in the Psychic matchup. Sludge Wave is Gengar's most powerful STAB attack and its best option for neutral damage. Focus Blast provides handy Fighting-type coverage that hits threats such as Excadrill, Heatran, and Tyranitar. Trick allows Gengar to cripple threats that would otherwise easily wall it, such as Gliscor.

Set Details

Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature and a Choice Scarf maximizes Gengar's Speed, allowing it to outpace the entire unboosted metagame and most of the boosted metagame. Maximum Special Attack investment gives Gengar as much damage output as possible. Cursed Body is Gengar's only ability and gives it a 30% chance to cripple opposing attackers.

Usage Tips

Gengar should primarily be used as a revenge killer and cleaner, picking off fast and weak threats with its superior Speed without taking damage. Utilize Gengar carefully in matchups where it is needed to check threats such as Mega Lopunny or where its STAB moves are particularly useful, such as in the Psychic matchup. Trick should be used to cripple threatening walls such as Gliscor and Zapdos. However, take care not to use Trick until threats such as Mega Lopunny, which Choice Scarf is needed to check, have been removed. Be careful using Gengar as a revenge killer while Pursuit trappers such as Alolan Muk and Mega Aerodactyl are healthy enough to check it. When picking a move to lock Gengar into, take into consideration that all of its attacks have types immune to them, granting free switches for certain Pokemon and affording the opponent undue momentum.

Team Options

Alolan Muk forms a strong Psychic breaker core with Gengar, as between the two of them, they can offensively and defensively check most Psychic-types; Alolan Muk traps Meloetta and Choice Scarf Latios and provides Knock Off support, while Gengar cleans weakened teams. Mega Venusaur and Toxapex form a powerful defensive backbone to support Gengar and whittle down its checks with Toxic Spikes, Leech Seed, and other sources of chip damage while also managing Gengar's offensive checks such as Greninja, Mega Charizard Y, and Azumarill. Crobat provides a handy Ground immunity and entry hazard remover that can support Gengar by minimizing the hazard damage it takes and by safely bringing it in with U-turn. Nidoking and Nihilego are complementary special attackers that can set Stealth Rock to punish the switches Gengar forces as a revenge killer. Nidoking also serves as a powerful special wallbreaker and helps apply severe pressure in the Flying and Steel matchups, where Gengar can struggle.

Marowak-Alola.overview:
Fire

Due to a great offensive typing in conjunction with a massive Attack stat thanks to Thick Club, Alolan Marowak makes for a strong wallbreaker on Fire teams. Its ability in Lightning Rod allows Alolan Marowak to block Electric-type moves, most notably Volt Switch, allowing it to be a great switch-in for Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Magnezone, which can give Alolan Marowak opportunities to dish out attacks. Alolan Marowak is a far more threatening Stealth Rock setter than the passive and more common Torkoal due to its ability to pressure common Defoggers such as Zapdos, Mantine, Skarmory, and Crobat thanks to its sky-high Attack stat. Due to its Ghost typing Alolan Marowak serves as a great spinblocker, allowing it to keep up Stealth Rock versus Bug teams. However, its slow base 45 Speed and average bulk cause Alolan Marowak to get revenge killed easily. It is often outclassed by other physical wallbreakers such as Infernape and Victini, as they possess better Speed tiers. Alolan Marowak is also vulnerable to all entry hazards and weak to Stealth Rock, which can wear it down quickly. It also does not appreciate Knock Off due to it relying on Thick Club to double its Attack stat, as without it, Alolan Marowak's wallbreaking potential is subpar.

Ghost

With Thick Club doubling its Attack, Alolan Marowak serves as a formidable wallbreaker on Ghost-type teams. Its access to Stealth Rock also allows it to double as an entry hazard setter. Alolan Marowak's ability, Lightning Rod, grants it an Electric immunity, which is particularly useful for checking Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko and Zapdos while also blocking Volt Switch. Its Fire typing along with Fire-type STAB moves grants it the ability to hit Grass-, Steel-, and Ice-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Alolan Ninetales for super effective damage. However, its Fire typing also burdens it with a weakness to Stealth Rock, along with weaknesses to common types in Ground, Rock, and Water. Due to its underwhelming bulk, Alolan Marowak often can only switch in on attacks it resists or is immune to. Alolan Marowak is overreliant on Thick Club for wallbreaking, meaning if it loses its item, it loses most of its offensive prowess. It is also easily outsped and revenge killed due to its poor Speed.
Marowak-Alola.comments:
Other Options

Fire

Swords Dance can be used to give Alolan Marowak monstrous wallbreaking potential; however, with its low Speed stat and subpar bulk, Alolan Marowak will rarely ever pull off a Swords Dance sweep.

Ghost

Swords Dance can be utilized on Alolan Marowak over Earthquake in order to break defensive cores more easily by taking advantage of switches, although Alolan Marowak is rarely sweeping with the boosts due to its low Speed and bulk. Bonemerang can be used over Earthquake in order to effectively take down Focus Sash Alolan Golem; however, many Alolan Golem carry Air Balloon, making the accuracy drop not worth it. Rock Head can be used in conjunction with Flare Blitz in to negate recoil, but the lack of Lightning Rod makes Alolan Marowak unable to check threatening Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko and Magnezone.

Checks and Counters

Fire

Super Effective Attacks: Water-types such as Keldeo, Mega Swampert, and Rotom-W, Rock-types such as Tyranitar, Mega Diancie, Terrakion, and Nihilego, Ground-type Pokemon like Excadrill, Landorus, and Garchomp, as well as Dark-type Pokemon such as Hydreigon, Bisharp, and Mega Sharpedo can all outspeed and KO Alolan Marowak with their STAB attacks.

Revenge Killers and Wallbreakers: Faster offensive threats such as Kyurem-B, Dragonite, and Kommo-o will easily outspeed and OHKO Alolan Marowak, as it has poor bulk.

Entry Hazards and Residual Damage: Being a grounded Fire-type, entry hazard damage from Stealth Rock and Spikes can wear down Alolan Marowak quickly and significantly; Toxic poison and Flare Blitz recoil can do so as well.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Alolan Marowak cannot OHKO certain physical walls such as Mandibuzz, Hippowdon, and Porygon2, and these examples all carry moves that can KO Alolan Marowak, such as Foul Play and Earthquake.

Ghost

Super Effective Coverage: Rock-, Dark-, Ground-, and Water-type Pokemon such as Mega Diancie, Hydreigon, Landorus, and Keldeo all knock Alolan Marowak out with their super effective STAB attacks.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Alolan Marowak has trouble breaking through certain physically defensive Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Porygon2, and Mandibuzz that it can't hit super effectively.

Faster Threats: Faster offensive Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Mega Gallade, and Kyurem-B take advantage of Alolan Marowak's poor Speed and bulk to threaten it.

Residual Damage: Chip damage obtained from entry hazards such as Stealth Rock and Spikes as well as poison and Flare Bliz's recoil wears Alolan Marowak down to the point where it has to rely on its low Speed to outspeed opposing Pokemon.

Utility Wallbreaker (Fire).description:
Moves

Stealth Rock provides the team with entry hazards, wearing down the opposing team throughout the match so Alolan Marowak's teammates can sweep easier. Shadow Bone hits a lot of the metagame hard, as a lot of teams lack Ghost-resistant Pokemon. Notably, it can be used to hit Slowbro for super effective damage. Flare Blitz is a powerful Fire-type STAB move that hits Pokemon such as Venusaur, Chansey, and Celesteela hard; however, using it alongside Lightning Rod may wear down Alolan Marowak. Fire Punch is a safer Fire-type STAB option for Grass and Steel teams, since Marowak's durability is valued more throughout the course of the match. Earthquake allows Alolan Marowak to hit Electric-, Poison-, and Rock-type Pokemon such as Alolan Golem, Alolan Muk, Toxapex, and Tyranitar for super effective damage.

Set Details

228 Speed EVs alongside a Jolly nature allow Alolan Marowak to outspeed all 200 Speed Pokemon such as Mega Venusaur, Mantine, and slower variants of Mandibuzz. Maximum Attack investment allows Alolan Marowak to hit as hard as possible in conjunction with Thick Club. The remaining EVs are put into HP to maximize its bulk and to give Alolan Marowak an odd HP value so it can switch in on Stealth Rock more times. Lightning Rod grants Alolan Marowak an Electric immunity, allowing it to counter Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Magnezone, as well as block Volt Switch.

Usage Tips

Alolan Marowak is a utility wallbreaker, so try and get it into battle as early as possible and switch it into resisted attacks or predicted Electric-type moves so that it essentially gets a free turn to set up Stealth Rock or dish out a powerful attack. It is very critical to keep Alolan Marowak healthy in Electric matchups, as it stops Pokemon such as Tapu Koko and Zapdos from going for their Electric-type STAB moves, which includes Volt Switch. Alolan Marowak should be used to wallbreak in the early-game to punch holes in the opposing team. It should prioritize getting up Stealth Rock versus Dragon, Dark, and other Fire teams, as Alolan Marowak does not have the best offensive matchups and can enforce entry hazard pressure on these teams. Alolan Marowak is also a great Stealth Rock user, as it can spinblock and thus keep up Stealth Rock versus Bug teams. It can also threaten potential Defoggers such as Zapdos, Skarmory, and Mantine. Choice Scarf Latios will also have to make a decision between going for a sacrificial Defog in order to get rid of Stealth Rock or attacking Alolan Marowak. It is critical for Alolan Marowak to avoid Knock Off users, as it will lose its Thick Club, which will then cut Alolan Marowak's Attack stat in half. Use Flare Blitz only to break through walls that resist or do not take enough damage from Shadow Bone, such as Mandibuzz, Mega Venusaur, and Chansey, as this will wear down Alolan Marowak unnecessarily.

Team Options

Mega Charizard Y is a complementary teammate for Alolan Marowak, as it provides sun support with its ability Drought and can threaten Water- and Ground-types with Solar Beam. Mega Charizard Y appreciates Alolan Marowak as a teammate due to its ability in Lightning Rod, as it can switch into threatening Electric-type attacks for Mega Charizard Y. Mega Charizard X is also great teammate for Alolan Marowak, as it has a much easier time sweeping Dragon teams once Stealth Rock is up. Mega Charizard X also appreciates Alolan Marowak's ability to punch holes through the opposing team, weakening them for Mega Charizard X to sweep. Volcarona also can get rid of Dark-types that threaten Alolan Marowak with Bug Buzz, and it appreciates Alolan Marowak setting up Stealth Rock for it, allowing it to sweep more easily. Infernape is another great teammate that can threaten Dark- and Rock-types and faster Pokemon that would otherwise be able to get rid of Alolan Marowak like Excadrill, Heatran, and Tyranitar. Heatran is also a great teammate, as it is able to trap and eliminate physical walls with Magma Storm, and without the need to run Stealth Rock on Heatran, it is free to run Flash Cannon in order to get rid of Mega Diancie. Victini can also benefit from Alolan Marowak's wallbreaking capabilities, as it can get rid of Psychic-types, which can then free up a late-game Z-Celebrate sweep. Rotom-H provides a Ground-type immunity, can pivot with Volt Switch, and can provide Defog support to aid Alolan Marowak from taking damage from entry hazards. Rotom-H also provides dual screens support and, in conjunction with Alolan Marowak's Stealth Rock, allows teammates to sweep more easily. Volcanion is a great partner for Alolan Marowak, as it provides a Water immunity and is a special wallbreaker that complements Alolan Marowak as a physical wallbreaker. Alolan Marowak also complements Volcanion, as it provides an Electric immunity with Lightning Rod.

Stealth Rock (Ghost).description:
Moves

Stealth Rock gradually chips away at foes residually upon entering the battle. Fire Punch is Alolan Marowak's STAB attack and hits Steel-, Ice-, and Grass-type Pokemon such as Celesteela, Alolan Ninetales, and Tapu Bulu for super effective damage. Flare Blitz is a more powerful alternative to Fire Punch that can 2HKO bulky foes such as Mega Venusaur and Chansey but can be worse in matchups such as Steel and Grass where Alolan Marowak values longevity. Shadow Bone is Alolan Marowak’s other STAB move that can be used to hit Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Slowbro and Jellicent super effectively while hitting the vast majority of the metagame along with Pokemon that resist Fire such as Rotom-W neutrally. Earthquake hits Poison-, Fire-, and Rock-type Pokemon such as Toxapex, Mega Charizard X, and Tyranitar for super effective damage.

Set Details

228 Speed EVs along with a Jolly nature allow Alolan Marowak to outpace Mega Venusaur and most Mantine variants. Thick Club along with 252 Attack EVs maximize Alolan Marowak's Attack and allow it to serve as an effective wallbreaker. The remaining 24 EVs are placed into Alolan Marowak's HP in order to improve its poor bulk. Lightning Rod gifts Alolan Marowak with an Electric immunity along with the ability to effectively check threatening Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Magnezone while also blocking Volt Switch.

Usage Tips

Because Alolan Marowak is Ghost's premier physical wallbreaker, it should try to find as many opportunities as it can during a battle to switch in and punch holes in the opposing team. As a result of Alolan Marowak’s poor bulk, try to switch it into resisted attacks such as Celesteela’s Heavy Slam, as any strong attack may blow it away. Steer away from Knock Off users such as Mew, as Alolan Marowak will take an enormous amount of damage while losing its Thick Club along with its offensive prowess, hindering its ability to effectively wallbreak. In matchups such as Dragon where Alolan Marowak won’t be of much use due to its poor Speed, prioritize finding openings to get up Stealth Rock so that its teammates will benefit from it. Similarily, in matchups such as Poison, Grass, and Steel where Alolan Marowak’s wallbreaking prowess is valued, keep Alolan Marowak healthy throughout the game so it can come in multiple times and wallbreak. Try to preserve Flare Blitz for bulkier targets, as the recoil will unnecessarily wear Alolan Marowak down if it's used too liberally. Create opportunities to set Stealth Rock safely by forcing the foe into unfavorable positions. For example, Toxapex may want to switch out in order to avoid being threatened by Earthquake, giving Alolan Marowak an opportunity to lay down the entry hazard. Try to keep Stealth Rock off the field before sending Alolan Marowak in in order to prevent it from getting chipped. If threatening Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko are still present on the opposing side, make sure to keep Alolan Marowak healthy enough to effectively check them with Lightning Rod.

Team Options

The entire Ghost team appreciates Alolan Marowak's ability to break through defensive threats such as Toxapex, Celesteela, and Alolan Muk. Mega Sableye is an amazing partner for Alolan Marowak, as it can switch into a plethora of attacks for it, including Dark-type attacks such as Knock Off, while keeping entry hazards off of the field and therefore keeping Alolan Marowak healthy due to its amazing ability in Magic Bounce. Mimikyu is able to check Dark-type Pokemon such as Mega Sharpedo and Hydreigon for Marowak with Play Rough. In return, Alolan Marowak is able to set Stealth Rock for Mimikyu, chipping the opponent's team and thus allowing it to sweep more easily late-game while also beating Steel-type Pokemon such as Celesteela, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn that Mimikyu struggles to damage. Alolan Marowak appreciates Jellicent's ability to switch into and sponge Water-type attacks such as Suicune's Scald for it. In return, Alolan Marowak can switch into and check Electric-type Pokemon such as Tapu Koko for Jellicent. Decidueye is able to switch into Water- and Ground-type attacks such as Keldeo's Hydro Pump and Excadrill's Earthquake for Alolan Marowak while also using Defog to clear away hazards and thus keeping Alolan Marowak healthy by avoiding chip damage. Gengar and Blacephalon both appreciate Alolan Marowak's ability to set Stealth Rock and chip the opposing team down, allowing them to clean more efficiently. They are also able to check faster Pokemon that threaten Alolan Marowak such as Hydreigon with Focus Blast and Garchomp with Hidden Power Ice, respectively.

Chansey.overview:
Normal

Chansey is one of the best walls in Monotype, and it is mandatory on balanced Normal-type teams because of the roles it provides. It has Eviolite to boost its bulk, Natural Cure to act as a status sponge, Soft-Boiled for reliable recovery, and access to useful utility moves such as Stealth Rock, Toxic, and Thunder Wave. Chansey forms potentially the best defensive core in the metagame with Porygon2 and Staraptor; this core is further supported by Ditto and strong priority users like Diggersby that prevent most forms of offensive counterplay. Unfortunately, Chansey saps any momentum due to its cripplingly low Speed and nonexistent offensive presence. It's also susceptible to stallbreakers such as Mew and is reliant on Eviolite, which means it'll be disadvantaged by Knock Off users like Bisharp and Trick users like Latios. Chansey's lack of an offensive presence causes it to be setup bait for Pokemon like Taunt Gyarados and Refresh Mega Altaria. Defensive Pokemon that Chansey struggles to break, such as Toxapex and Ferrothorn, can also freely set entry hazards against it.
Chansey.comments:
Other Options

Normal

Thunder Wave lets Chansey cripple Pokemon like Mega Pinsir and Kommo-o so that slower teammates like Diggersby can outpace and KO them. Aromatherapy lets Chansey act as a cleric but usually isn't worth it because Chansey can absorb status with Natural Cure. Wish lets Chansey heal teammates but isn't very useful because some of its teammates like Staraptor and Porygon2 already have reliable recovery. When running it, Chansey also has to give up important utility like Toxic.

Checks and Counters

Normal

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Terrakion outpace and KO Chansey.

Trick and Knock Off: Pokemon like Bisharp and Mega Sableye cripple Chansey with Knock Off. Pokemon like Latios can turn Chansey into a liability by using Trick.

Setup Sweepers: Mega Charizard X, Mega Scizor, and Refresh Mega Latias all use Chansey as setup bait.
